title: Matthew Chapter 28 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 28 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 28 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 28.

questions.question: Who came to see the sepulchre as it began to dawn toward the first day of the week?
options: Mary Magdalene and the other Mary
Peter and John
The eleven disciples
The chief priests
questions.correctAnswer: Mary Magdalene and the other Mary
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:1 states that Mary Magdalene and the other Mary came to see the sepulchre at dawn toward the first day of the week.

questions.question: What supernatural event occurred when the angel of the Lord descended from heaven?
options: A great earthquake
A fire from heaven
A strong wind
A loud trumpet sound
questions.correctAnswer: A great earthquake
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:2 describes a great earthquake that happened as the angel of the Lord descended from heaven.

questions.question: How was the angel's countenance described?
options: Like lightning
Like the sun
Like a cloud
Like fire
questions.correctAnswer: Like lightning
questions.explanation: According to Matthew 28:3, the angel's countenance was like lightning.

questions.question: What happened to the keepers because of fear of the angel?
options: They shook and became as dead men
They ran away
They shouted for help
They fell asleep
questions.correctAnswer: They shook and became as dead men
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:4 says the keepers shook for fear and became as dead men.

questions.question: What did the angel tell the women not to do?
options: Fear not
Run away
Hide
Cry
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not
questions.explanation: In Matthew 28:5, the angel instructs the women not to fear.

questions.question: What was the angel's message about Jesus' body?
options: He is not here; he is risen
He was stolen by his disciples
He is still in the tomb
He has gone to Galilee alone
questions.correctAnswer: He is not here; he is risen
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:6 states that Jesus is not in the tomb because he has risen.

questions.question: Where did the angel say Jesus would go before the disciples?
options: Into Galilee
Into Jerusalem
Into Samaria
Into Judea
questions.correctAnswer: Into Galilee
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:7 says the angel told the women that Jesus goes before them into Galilee.

questions.question: How did the women feel as they departed from the sepulchre?
options: With fear and great joy
With sadness and confusion
With anger and doubt
With silence and sorrow
questions.correctAnswer: With fear and great joy
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:8 describes the women departing quickly with fear and great joy.

questions.question: What did Jesus say to the women when they met Him?
options: All hail
Go away
Do not touch me
Be silent
questions.correctAnswer: All hail
questions.explanation: As per Matthew 28:9, Jesus greeted the women with 'All hail' when they met Him.

questions.question: What were the women instructed to do after meeting Jesus?
options: Tell his brethren to go into Galilee
Keep the resurrection a secret
Return to the tomb
Tell the chief priests
questions.correctAnswer: Tell his brethren to go into Galilee
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:10 records Jesus instructing the women to tell his brethren to go into Galilee.

questions.question: True or False: The chief priests gave money to the soldiers to say that Jesus was stolen by his disciples.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:12-13 explains that the chief priests paid the soldiers to say Jesus' disciples stole his body.

questions.question: True or False: The eleven disciples went to a mountain in Galilee where Jesus had appointed them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:16 states the eleven disciples went to a mountain in Galilee where Jesus had appointed them.

questions.question: True or False: When the disciples saw Jesus, all of them worshipped Him without doubt.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:17 says some disciples doubted even though they worshipped Jesus.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'All power is given unto me in heaven and in ______.'
options: earth
hell
the church
Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: earth
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:18 states all power is given in heaven and in earth.

questions.question: According to Jesus' command, what are the disciples to do to all nations?
options: Teach and baptize
Ignore them
Conquer them
Only preach in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Teach and baptize
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:19 commands the disciples to teach all nations and baptize them.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 28 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 28 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear after facing a difficult trial. Based on Matthew 28, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them?
options: Fear not, for Jesus has risen and is with you always.
You should rely only on your own strength.
Doubt is a sign of weak faith.
Trials mean God has abandoned you.
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not, for Jesus has risen and is with you always.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:5, 28:6, and 28:20 teach us that Jesus has risen and promises to be with us always, encouraging us to fear not despite trials.

questions.question: How does Matthew 28 teach us about the importance of obedience and sharing the Gospel?
options: Go and teach all nations, baptizing and instructing them.
Keep the resurrection a secret among close friends.
Preach only to those who already believe.
Wait for perfect conditions before sharing the Gospel.
questions.correctAnswer: Go and teach all nations, baptizing and instructing them.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:19-20 commands believers to teach, baptize, and share Jesus' teachings with all nations, emphasizing obedience and evangelism.

questions.question: A believer doubts Jesus' resurrection and presence. What truth from Matthew 28 can you share to strengthen their faith?
options: Jesus showed himself to the disciples and has all power in heaven and earth.
Doubt means you are not saved.
Faith requires never questioning anything.
Belief is optional for discipleship.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus showed himself to the disciples and has all power in heaven and earth.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:17-18 records that Jesus appeared to the disciples and declared all authority, reinforcing the reality of His resurrection and power.

questions.question: What can Matthew 28 teach us about humility and worship in response to Jesus' resurrection?
options: The women and disciples worshipped Jesus, showing reverence and humility.
Worship is optional after resurrection.
Only priests should worship Jesus.
Worship is unnecessary because Jesus is not physically present.
questions.correctAnswer: The women and disciples worshipped Jesus, showing reverence and humility.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:9 and 28:17 show that those who saw the risen Jesus worshipped Him, demonstrating humility and reverence.

questions.question: A fellow believer asks about perseverance through trials. How does Matthew 28 encourage perseverance?
options: Jesus promises to be with us always, even to the end of the age.
Only the strongest survive trials.
Trials prove God’s displeasure.
Perseverance is unnecessary if you pray enough.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus promises to be with us always, even to the end of the age.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:20 assures believers of Jesus’ continual presence, encouraging perseverance through any challenge.

questions.question: How does Matthew 28 instruct believers regarding integrity and honesty in their witness?
options: Believers are to honestly proclaim Jesus’ resurrection and teachings.
It is acceptable to fabricate stories to gain followers.
Keeping silent about Jesus’ resurrection is best.
Only religious leaders should speak about Jesus.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are to honestly proclaim Jesus’ resurrection and teachings.
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes truthful witness of Jesus’ resurrection (Matthew 28:6-7) despite opposition or false claims (Matthew 28:12-15).

questions.question: A believer is hesitant to share the Gospel fearing rejection. What practical teaching from Matthew 28 encourages boldness?
options: Jesus instructs us to go quickly and tell the disciples He is risen.
It is safer to remain silent about faith.
Only share the Gospel with close friends.
Evangelism should wait for public approval.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus instructs us to go quickly and tell the disciples He is risen.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:7 commands believers to promptly share the good news of Jesus’ resurrection, encouraging bold and immediate witness.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 28 teaches that Jesus’ resurrection is a foundation for believers to live with hope and confidence.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The resurrection is the cornerstone of Christian hope, as shown in Matthew 28:6 and Jesus’ assurance of His power and presence in verses 18 and 20.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 28, some disciples doubted even after seeing the risen Jesus.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:17 states that when the disciples saw Jesus, some worshipped Him but others doubted, showing that faith can coexist with doubt.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jesus gave the disciples the Great Commission to go and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the _______, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.
options: Father
Son
Spirit
Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Father
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:19 specifically instructs baptism in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, emphasizing the Trinity.

questions.question: What example does Matthew 28 provide about trusting God's promises even when circumstances seem impossible?
options: Jesus rose from the dead as He promised, demonstrating God’s faithfulness.
God’s promises are conditional on perfect behavior.
Miracles only happen in the Old Testament.
The resurrection was a symbolic story only.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus rose from the dead as He promised, demonstrating God’s faithfulness.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:6 confirms Jesus rose 'as he said,' showing God's trustworthiness and encouraging believers to trust His promises.

questions.question: How does Matthew 28 teach us about the role of prayer and personal devotion in Christian life?
options: Jesus’ promise to be with us always encourages continual devotion and trust.
Prayer is only necessary for leaders.
Devotion is unnecessary after salvation.
Only public worship matters.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus’ promise to be with us always encourages continual devotion and trust.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:20’s promise of Jesus’ continual presence supports ongoing prayer and devotion as vital for spiritual life.

questions.question: In what way does Matthew 28 encourage believers to serve others within the church and community?
options: By teaching and baptizing all nations, believers serve others by spreading the Gospel.
Serving is optional and only for clergy.
Evangelism should be done privately only.
Service is only about financial giving.
questions.correctAnswer: By teaching and baptizing all nations, believers serve others by spreading the Gospel.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:19-20 emphasizes active teaching and baptizing, showing service through sharing God’s Word.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with doubt about Jesus’ resurrection. What practical advice based on Matthew 28 would you give?
options: Remember that Jesus appeared to His disciples and was worshipped, even though some doubted.
Doubt is unforgivable and should be ignored.
Ignore the resurrection stories and focus on other scriptures.
Only accept teachings that are easy to understand.
questions.correctAnswer: Remember that Jesus appeared to His disciples and was worshipped, even though some doubted.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:17 acknowledges some doubt among disciples but also their worship, encouraging honest faith and trust.

questions.question: How can Matthew 28 guide a believer in maintaining gratitude and contentment amid daily challenges?
options: By trusting Jesus’ resurrection and ongoing presence, believers can be content and thankful.
Contentment comes from material wealth.
Gratitude is not important in trials.
Only positive circumstances warrant thankfulness.
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting Jesus’ resurrection and ongoing presence, believers can be content and thankful.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:20’s promise that Jesus is with us always encourages gratitude and contentment regardless of circumstances.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 28 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 28.

questions.question: In Matthew 28:2, what event accompanies the angel of the Lord descending from heaven?
options: A great earthquake
A loud trumpet blast
A violent storm
A darkening of the sky
questions.correctAnswer: A great earthquake
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:2 describes a great earthquake occurring as the angel of the Lord descends and rolls back the stone from the sepulchre.

questions.question: What is the significance of the angel's countenance being like lightning and his raiment white as snow in Matthew 28:3?
options: It symbolizes divine purity and power
It represents fear and judgment
It indicates earthly royalty
It reflects the dawn of a new day
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes divine purity and power
questions.explanation: The lightning-like countenance and snow-white raiment of the angel in Matthew 28:3 emphasize his divine nature, purity, and heavenly authority.

questions.question: According to Matthew 28:6, what is the main message the angel delivers to the women at the sepulchre?
options: He is not here; He is risen as He said
The tomb is guarded by soldiers
They should return home quietly
Jesus will appear in Jerusalem soon
questions.correctAnswer: He is not here; He is risen as He said
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:6 clearly states that Jesus is not in the tomb because He has risen, fulfilling His previous prophecy.

questions.question: What instruction does the angel give the women regarding Jesus' disciples in Matthew 28:7?
options: Tell the disciples that Jesus has risen and will meet them in Galilee
Tell the disciples to stay in Jerusalem
Tell the disciples to prepare for a feast
Tell the disciples to hide from the authorities
questions.correctAnswer: Tell the disciples that Jesus has risen and will meet them in Galilee
questions.explanation: In Matthew 28:7, the angel instructs the women to quickly inform the disciples that Jesus has risen and will go before them to Galilee.

questions.question: In Matthew 28:9, how do the women respond upon meeting the risen Jesus?
options: They hold Him by the feet and worship Him
They run away in fear
They question His identity
They ask for a sign
questions.correctAnswer: They hold Him by the feet and worship Him
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:9 recounts that the women worship Jesus by holding His feet when He greets them.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the chief priests giving money to the soldiers in Matthew 28:12-13?
options: To persuade them to spread a false story that Jesus' disciples stole His body
To pay them for guarding the tomb properly
To bribe them to become disciples of Jesus
To secure their silence about the resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: To persuade them to spread a false story that Jesus' disciples stole His body
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:12-13 explains that the chief priests bribed soldiers to claim Jesus' disciples stole His body, creating a false narrative to counter the resurrection.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'all power is given unto me in heaven and in earth' in Matthew 28:18 imply about Jesus' authority?
options: Jesus has universal authority over both the spiritual and earthly realms
Jesus only has authority in heaven
Jesus shares power equally with the disciples
Jesus speaks metaphorically about his influence
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus has universal authority over both the spiritual and earthly realms
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:18 asserts Jesus' supreme and comprehensive authority over all creation, both heavenly and earthly.

questions.question: In Matthew 28:19, the command to baptize 'in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost' reflects what theological concept?
options: The doctrine of the Trinity
The unity of Israel
The authority of the Jewish law
The concept of messianic prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: The doctrine of the Trinity
questions.explanation: The triune formula in Matthew 28:19 evidences the Christian doctrine of the Trinity, affirming the distinct persons of Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.

questions.question: How does the mention of Galilee in Matthew 28:7 and 28:10 connect to earlier narratives in Matthew's Gospel?
options: Galilee was where Jesus began His public ministry
Galilee was the location of Jesus' crucifixion
Galilee was the place of the Last Supper
Galilee was the hometown of the disciples only
questions.correctAnswer: Galilee was where Jesus began His public ministry
questions.explanation: Galilee, referenced in Matthew 28:7 and 28:10, is significant as the region where Jesus began His ministry, thus symbolizing a return to the starting point of His mission.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in Matthew 28:6 where the angel says, 'He is not here: for he is risen, as he said'?
options: Fulfillment of prophecy
Paradox
Simile
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Fulfillment of prophecy
questions.explanation: The statement in Matthew 28:6 reflects Jesus' prior predictions about His resurrection, demonstrating fulfillment of prophecy.

questions.question: What does the trembling and becoming 'as dead men' of the keepers in Matthew 28:4 reveal about the ancient Near Eastern cultural response to divine encounters?
options: Fear and awe in the presence of divine beings
Physical weakness from illness
Disbelief and skepticism
Joy and celebration
questions.correctAnswer: Fear and awe in the presence of divine beings
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:4 shows that the guards' fearful reaction aligns with ancient cultural responses of trembling and shock when encountering divine manifestations.

questions.question: Why might Matthew have included the detail that 'some doubted' when the disciples saw Jesus in Matthew 28:17?
options: To acknowledge human uncertainty even among believers
To discredit the resurrection
To show that Jesus was a ghost
To emphasize the failure of the disciples
questions.correctAnswer: To acknowledge human uncertainty even among believers
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:17’s mention of doubt highlights the realistic and honest portrayal of the disciples' initial struggle to fully grasp the resurrection.

questions.question: In Matthew 28:20, Jesus promises 'I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world.' This statement most closely connects to which Old Testament theme?
options: God’s covenantal presence with His people
The promise of a Davidic king
The establishment of the Mosaic law
The exile and restoration of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenantal presence with His people
questions.explanation: Jesus’ promise in Matthew 28:20 echoes the Old Testament theme of God’s abiding presence with His covenant people throughout history.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 28:15, the story that Jesus' body was stolen by disciples is a widely reported belief among the Jews.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:15 states that the bribed soldiers' claim about the disciples stealing Jesus' body is commonly reported among the Jews.

questions.question: The angel rolling back the stone in Matthew 28:2 can be seen as a typological reversal of which Old Testament event?
options: The stone rolled away from the cave of the patriarchs’ tomb
The sealing of the Ark of the Covenant in the Holy of Holies
The closing of the Red Sea after the Israelites crossed
The stone tablets of the law being given to Moses
questions.correctAnswer: The stone rolled away from the cave of the patriarchs’ tomb
questions.explanation: The rolling away of the stone in Matthew 28:2 echoes typologically the opening of tombs or burial sites, symbolizing victory over death, which contrasts with the permanence of death in the Old Testament narrative.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 28 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 28 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the angel's declaration, 'He is not here: for he is risen,' in Matthew 28:6?
options: It affirms the bodily resurrection of Jesus, confirming His victory over death.
It suggests Jesus never actually died on the cross.
It implies Jesus' spirit left but His body remained in the tomb.
It denies the resurrection and emphasizes a spiritual presence only.
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms the bodily resurrection of Jesus, confirming His victory over death.
questions.explanation: Matthew 28:6 explicitly states the resurrection, a cornerstone of Christian faith affirming Jesus' victory over death and sin, consistent with Romans 6:9, 1 Corinthians 15:4, Acts 2:24, and John 11:25.

questions.question: In Matthew 28:18, Jesus claims, 'All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth.' What doctrine does this statement most directly support?
options: The universal sovereignty and divine authority of Christ.
The limited authority of Jesus only on earth.
Jesus as a prophet without divine authority.
The exclusive authority of God the Father alone.
questions.correctAnswer: The universal sovereignty and divine authority of Christ.
questions.explanation: Jesus' declaration affirms His divine lordship over all creation, supporting the doctrine of Christ's exaltation and deity, consistent with Philippians 2:9-11, Colossians 1:16-17, Hebrews 1:3, and Revelation 19:16.

questions.question: According to Matthew 28:19, what is the Trinitarian formula given for baptism?
options: In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.
In the name of Jesus Christ only.
In the name of the Father and the Son only.
In the name of the Spirit alone.
questions.correctAnswer: In the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.
questions.explanation: This verse explicitly commands baptism into the triune Godhead, affirming the doctrine of the Trinity consistent with Matthew 3:16-17, 2 Corinthians 13:14, John 14:16-17, and Ephesians 4:4-6.

questions.question: What is the eschatological promise Jesus gives in Matthew 28:20?
options: I am with you always, even unto the end of the world.
The world will end before His return.
His disciples will never face persecution.
He will return immediately to establish an earthly kingdom.
questions.correctAnswer: I am with you always, even unto the end of the world.
questions.explanation: Jesus promises His continual presence with His followers until the consummation of history, affirming eschatological hope and divine presence, consistent with Hebrews 13:5, John 14:16-18, Psalm 46:1, and Revelation 22:20.

questions.question: In Matthew 28:11-15, the chief priests bribed the soldiers to say Jesus' body was stolen. What apologetic concern does this address?
options: It counters claims that the resurrection was a fabrication by Jesus’ disciples.
It supports the claim that Jesus never rose from the dead.
It denies the existence of the empty tomb.
It suggests Jesus was secretly buried elsewhere.
questions.correctAnswer: It counters claims that the resurrection was a fabrication by Jesus’ disciples.
questions.explanation: This passage reveals early attempts to explain away the resurrection, highlighting the historical reality of the empty tomb against false accusations, aligned with 1 Corinthians 15:12-17, Luke 24:11, Acts 4:33, and John 20:27.

questions.question: How does Matthew 28:17 reflect the nature of faith among Jesus’ disciples after His resurrection?
options: It shows that worship and doubt can coexist among believers.
It demonstrates complete, unwavering faith without hesitation.
It indicates the disciples rejected Jesus' resurrection.
It reveals that no one believed in the resurrection at first.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that worship and doubt can coexist among believers.
questions.explanation: The verse acknowledges human struggle with faith even amid worship, showing the reality of doubt in the Christian experience, consistent with Thomas' doubt (John 20:24-29), Mark 9:24, Psalm 73:26, and James 1:6.

questions.question: What role does the earthquake in Matthew 28:2 play in the theological narrative?
options: It symbolizes God's power breaking the bonds of death.
It indicates a natural disaster unrelated to Jesus’ resurrection.
It serves only to frighten the guards without spiritual meaning.
It shows that the angel's arrival caused chaos, not divine power.
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's power breaking the bonds of death.
questions.explanation: The earthquake marks a divine intervention demonstrating God's authority over creation and death, consistent with Exodus 19:18, Psalm 18:7, Isaiah 54:10, and Hebrews 12:26.

questions.question: In Matthew 28:5, the angel tells the women, 'Fear not ye: for I know that ye seek Jesus, which was crucified.' What does this reveal about the nature of Jesus' mission?
options: It underscores Jesus' suffering and death as fulfillment of redemptive purpose.
It denies that Jesus was crucified.
It suggests Jesus' death was accidental.
It implies Jesus’ mission was incomplete.
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores Jesus' suffering and death as fulfillment of redemptive purpose.
questions.explanation: The angel acknowledges the crucifixion as a known, necessary event within God’s salvific plan, consistent with Isaiah 53:5, Luke 24:26, 1 Peter 2:24, and John 3:16.

questions.question: What does the instruction in Matthew 28:7 to 'go quickly, and tell his disciples that he is risen' teach about the role of the church?
options: The church is commissioned to proclaim the resurrection message urgently.
The church should keep the resurrection a secret.
The resurrection message is only for a select few.
The church should focus on worship without outreach.
questions.correctAnswer: The church is commissioned to proclaim the resurrection message urgently.
questions.explanation: This command establishes the evangelistic mission of the church to spread the gospel, consistent with Acts 1:8, Mark 16:15, Romans 10:14, and 2 Timothy 4:2.

questions.question: How does Matthew 28:10 demonstrate the continuation of Jesus’ earthly ministry after His resurrection?
options: Jesus personally commissions His followers and reassures them not to fear.
Jesus ceases all communication with His followers.
Jesus commands the disciples to abandon their mission.
Jesus appears only to the religious leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus personally commissions His followers and reassures them not to fear.
questions.explanation: Jesus' meeting with the women affirms His ongoing ministry and care, encouraging faith and obedience, consistent with Luke 24:36-49, John 20:19-21, Acts 1:4-8, and Hebrews 7:25.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus meeting the women on their way to tell the disciples, as described in Matthew 28:9?
options: It shows the reality of the resurrection through physical appearance and worship.
It suggests the resurrection was a vision only.
It indicates Jesus appeared only spiritually without a body.
It implies the women misunderstood the events.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the reality of the resurrection through physical appearance and worship.
questions.explanation: Jesus’ meeting and the women's worship affirm His bodily resurrection, consistent with Luke 24:39, John 20:27, 1 Corinthians 15:6, and Acts 10:41.

questions.question: In Matthew 28:16, Jesus meets the eleven disciples on a mountain in Galilee. What doctrinal truth is highlighted by this setting?
options: The appointed meeting place signifies divine authority and covenant renewal.
The location is irrelevant to the message.
It symbolizes Jesus' rejection of the disciples.
It indicates Jesus’ ministry is now confined to Galilee only.
questions.correctAnswer: The appointed meeting place signifies divine authority and covenant renewal.
questions.explanation: Mountains often symbolize divine encounters and covenantal moments in Scripture, paralleling Sinai (Exodus 19), the Transfiguration (Matthew 17), and the Great Commission, consistent with Hebrews 12:18-20, Psalm 2:6, and Isaiah 2:3.

questions.question: What does the angel's appearance and clothing in Matthew 28:3 symbolize about the divine nature of the resurrection event?
options: His countenance like lightning and raiment white as snow signify divine purity and power.
His appearance was ordinary and human-like.
He was described as dark and frightening.
His clothing indicated earthly status only.
questions.correctAnswer: His countenance like lightning and raiment white as snow signify divine purity and power.
questions.explanation: The angel’s dazzling appearance reflects holiness and heavenly authority, consistent with Daniel 10:6, Ezekiel 1:27, Revelation 1:14-16, and Exodus 34:29-30.

questions.question: How does the shaking of the guards in Matthew 28:4 contribute to understanding the power of God in the resurrection narrative?
options: It shows that God's presence causes fear and reveals His overwhelming power.
It implies the guards were faking their fear.
It indicates the guards were unaffected by the event.
It suggests natural causes unrelated to the resurrection.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that God's presence causes fear and reveals His overwhelming power.
questions.explanation: The guards' fear and paralysis demonstrate the supernatural power accompanying resurrection, consistent with Exodus 14:24, Isaiah 6:5, Revelation 1:17, and Psalm 34:7.

questions.question: What does the command in Matthew 28:20 to 'teach them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you' imply about the nature of Christian discipleship?
options: Discipleship involves both teaching doctrine and obedience to Jesus’ commands.
Discipleship is only about personal belief without action.
It suggests discipleship ends with the resurrection event.
It focuses solely on ritual practices without moral teaching.
questions.correctAnswer: Discipleship involves both teaching doctrine and obedience to Jesus’ commands.
questions.explanation: Jesus mandates comprehensive instruction and obedience, integral to the Great Commission, consistent with John 14:15, James 1:22, Luke 6:46, and 2 Timothy 3:16-17.
